key_title: Key to the species of Pimelea

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Thymelaeaceae

source.author: Entwisle, T.J.
source.title: Thymelaeaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: From: Entwisle, T.J. (1996). Thymelaeaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Stems hairy for at least a few internodes below each inflorescence; leaves hairy or glabrous
Stems glabrous or rarely with a few hairs on peduncle but not on internodes below; leaves glabrous
Style-portion of floral tube sparsely to moderately hairy inside for at least a short portion of its length
Floral tube glabrous inside
Leaves alternate or opposite; stamens much shorter than sepals, often subsessile; anthers flat, locules opening towards centre of flower
Leaves opposite; stamens shorter or longer than sepals; anthers not flat but sometimes shallowly triangular in transverse section, locules not (or rarely almost) opening towards centre of flower
Leaves 3–18 mm long, hairy on upper surface (at least when young); involucral bracts 6–12, hairy on both surfaces; flowers 25 or more per head
Leaves less than 8 mm long, glabrous on upper surface; involucral bracts 3–6, glabrous inside; flowers 3–18 per head
Repeatedly branched shrub to 2.5 m high; involucral bracts 2 or 4, elliptic to broadly elliptic, glabrous inside, shortly petiolate
Little branched shrub to 0.5 m high; involucral bracts 4 or rarely 6, more or less ovate, hairy inside, sessile
Inflorescence terminal with more than 2 flowers or axillary
Inflorescence of 1 or 2 terminal flowers; prostrate plant of alps and subalps
Fruit dry, enclosed in persistent base of floral tube
Fruit succulent, naked at maturity; Wilsons Promontory
Flower heads terminal or less commonly axillary; involucral bracts (if present) not subtended by minute sessile bracts
Flower heads axillary; involucral bracts papery, petiolate, subtended by minute sessile bracts; widespread shrub of mountains and foothills
Floral tube more than 2.5 mm long
Floral tube less than 2.5 mm long; shrub with glabrous leaves of rocky areas west of Melbourne
Involucral bracts absent or 2
Involucral bracts 4–8
Inflorescence at maturity elongate, more than 20 mm long, interrupted, not subtended by leaves at maturity
Inflorescence at maturity compact, less than 20 mm long, usually closely subtended by leaves
Leaves usually 4–6 times as long as wide; flowers with all hairs white, the hairs uniform or variable in size
Leaves usually 2–3 times as long as wide; flowers with both long brown hairs (although often white in bud) and minute hairs
Perennial shrub; leaves alternate or opposite; inflorescence of 1 or more terminal and/or axillary heads, each 3-many-flowered
Herbaceous or semi-woody annual; leaves always alternate; inflorescence terminal, dense, many-flowered; far north-west Victoria
Leaf upper surface glabrous or with hairs shorter and fewer than on lower surface, the lower surface sparsely to densely hairy; perianth 4.5–12 mm long, style portion of floral tube 1–5 mm long
Leaf surface covered with fine white appressed hairs, at least when young; perianth 3–4.5 mm long, style-portion of floral tube poorly defined, c. 0.8 mm long; mostly north-west Victoria
Floral tube glabrous outside (lobes may be hairy outside)
Floral tube at least partially hairy outside
Pedicel hairy
Pedicel glabrous
Involucral bracts distinctly thinner-textured than leaves; floral tube c. 15 mm long; Grampians
Involucral bracts similar to leaves in texture; floral tube 1–3 mm long
Shrub 1–3 m high, branchlets not spinescent
Subshrub less than 30 cm high, with spinescent branchlets
Flowers unisexual; ovary-portion of floral tube in female flowers longer than style-portion
Flowers bisexual or female; ovary-portion of floral tube shorter than style portion in flower (but not necessarily in fruit)
Subshrub or shrub, 20 cm to 3 m high; branchlets not spinescent
Subshrub, 5–30 cm high, with more or less spinescent branchlets; exceedingly rare, Wimmera
Flowers in axillary heads; mostly moist forests and alpine shrublands
Flowers in terminal heads; mallee areas of north-west
Ovary portion of floral tube glabrous on outer surface, at least in proximal half
Outer surface of floral tube hairy throughout or almost throughout (sometimes with almost glabrous ovary-portion in fruit)
Involucral bracts 4, green throughout; ovary-portion of floral tube entirely glabrous outside
Involucral bracts 9–11, cream at base; ovary-portion of floral tube hairy outside in distal half; far north-east Victoria
Involucral bracts with inside surface glabrous or only partially hairy; stamens with a definite filament; style exserted
Involucral bracts with inside surface covered in long, soft hairs; stamens almost sessile; style not or scarcely exserted
Leaves distributed along branches; floral tube more than 5 mm long
Leaves crowded and confined to end of each branch; floral tube less than 6 mm long; alpine
Leaves with lateral veins distinct on lower surface; floral tube with mixture of long and short hairs below circumscission point
Leaves with only the midrib distinct on lower surface; floral tube with hairs all similar in size below circumscission point
